question: 1 (c)
sols_html:
From the question, we immediately see that

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle \Delta x = \frac{1}{n}\end{aligned}\]

Now, to determine \(\displaystyle x_{i}\), notice that we have that the function is of the form

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle f(x_{i}) = \frac{1}{1 + (\tfrac{i}{n})^{2}}.\end{aligned}\]

The only composition of functions is underneath the square sign. So we must have that

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle f(x) = \frac{1}{1 + x^{2}}\end{aligned}\]

and hence that

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle x_{i} = \frac{i}{n}\end{aligned}\]

As \(\displaystyle x_{i} = a + i\Delta x\), we have that \(\displaystyle a = 0\) and hence since

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle \Delta x = \frac{1}{n} = \frac{b-a}{n} = \frac{b}{n}\end{aligned}\]

we have that \(\displaystyle b = 1\). Combining the above gives

\[\begin{aligned} \lim_{n \to \infty}\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i=1}^{n}\frac{1}{1 + (\tfrac{i}{n})^{2}} = \int_{0}^{1}\frac{1}{1 + x^{2}}\,dx\end{aligned}\]

which completes the question.
